Translation of 楚竹書・民之父母(en) into English.

p.seg: Zi Xia asked Confucius:
“In the Odes it is said:
“the joyous and pleasant lord
is the father and mother of the people.” (Mao 251).
How should one be
to be called father and mother of the people?
Confucius answered:
“To be the father and mother of the people
one has to attain the source of ritual propriety and music,
thereby reaching “the five outmost”,
thereby enacting “the three without”,
thereby pervading all-under-Heaven.
When there is a defeat from any direction,
he necessarily knows it first,
and so (can) be called the father and mother of the people.”
Zi Xia said:
“May I ask
what you refer to as “the five outmost”?
Confucius answered:
“The five outmost [means that]
when the outmost is reached by the (myriad) creatures,
the intent also reaches there [the heart mind follows the myriad transformations?];
when the outmost is reached by the intent,
ritual propriety also reaches there;
when the outmost is reached by ritual propriety,
music also reaches there;
when the outmost is reached by music,
grief also reaches there;
grief and music/joy generate each other,
and the gentleman thereby is correct-
Zi Xia said:
“I have now heard about the Five Outmost,
may I ask what you refer as the “three without”?
Confucius said:
"The three without,
are music without sound,
rituals without embodiment,
and mourning without (mourning) garb.
The gentleman by means of this shines all-under-heaven.
If one turns his ears to listen to it,
he does not get to hear it;
if one brightens his eyes to look for it,
he does not get to see it,
but his (=of the sage) virtue already pervades (everything) within the four seas,
this is what I call “the three without”.
Zi Xia said:
“Music without sound,
rituals without embodiment,
and mourning without (mourning) garb,
which record (better) approaches this (topic)?
Confucius said:
Good (question), Shang!
I think I can (start to) teach you about the Odes.
“King Cheng did not dare to dwell in happy idleness,
morning and evening he laid the foundations of his (appointment=) great task” (Mao 271),
this is music without sound;
“my dignified demeanor has been perfect,
[you cannot (count=) measure it.” (Ode 26),
this is ritual without embodiment;
whenever people met with disaster,
I crawled on my knees to succour them. (ode 35).
This is mourning without mourning garb.
Zi Xia said:
"These words of his
are really beautiful!
Majestic!
Great!
It is all [about it}?
Confucius said:
How could it be so!
There are also the five beginnings.
Zi Xia said:
What you refer as the five beginnings], could I get to hear about it?
Confucius said:
“In music without sound,
pneuma and intent do not run against (each other);
when there is ritual without embodiment,
the dignified demeanour is perfect (Ode 26);
when there is mourning without mourning garb,
there is an inward reciprocity, and deep pitifulness.
When there is music without sounds,
it fills the four regions,
when there is ritual without embodiments,
it advances every day and brings help every month,
when there is mourning without mourning garb,
a pure virtue is unified and brilliant.
When there is music without sound,
it spreads and reaches the descendants;
when there is ritual without embodiment,
it fills everything within the four seas,
when there is mourning without mourning garb,
one is the father and mother of the people.
When there is music without sound,
pneuma and intent have already been obtained;
when there is ritual without embodiment,
the dignified demeanor is great;
when there is mourning without mourning garb,
it spreads and reaches the states in all directions,
